title: The Politician’s Husband (again)
body:
In light of recent developments in politics (re: Jo Johnson resigning from government over Brexit), it felt like an appropriate time to rewatch The Politician’s Husband (which I’ve been planning on doing for a few months now). 

I’ve just rewatched the first episode - the other two will wait for tomorrow, because apparently I’m sick again (yay) - but I’ve already got all these thoughts running through my head that I really needed to share.

1. It’s like it’s written for today

Aiden’s entire resignation speech is about the government’s stance on immigration, about cabinet members wanting to turn the UK into “Fortress Britain”, about how they’re playing the public’s xenophobia for their advantage. I’m thinking, surely, surely they didn’t think the UK would come to such terrible times when they made this in 2013, did they? Yet it’s like this whole speech was written for today, for Brexit, for the government that keeps pushing it forward while the country clearly doesn’t want it. It’s like this whole thing was written for today.

And I mean, TODAY. Exactly in time for Johnson’s resignation. It’s almost like we’re living the show, right now. Except it’s actually worse. And if things don’t change, and quickly, Britain might just find itself torn to pieces. And alone.

I would’ve written more, but somehow I get the feeling the similarities between our lives and the show just pop up. Watch it. You’ll see it.

SPOILER WARNING - Spoilers all the way to the end from here

2. Corruption of the best is the worst of all.

It always pains me to watch the beginning of The Politician’s Husband, knowing how it ends. Other than that misguided resignation (thanks to his back-stabbing, son-of-a-bitch “best friend”), he generally came to it from the right reasons. He wanted to change things. He wanted to do good. And in his core, he’s a good man. You can see it in the way he interacts with his family, the way he tries to protect Freya when she rises to fame, the way he’s shattered when he realises he’s been betrayed by Bruce and his own ego, even the way he listens to what the people have to say. He doesn’t have to do any of it. But his heart is in the right place.

It’s betrayal that pushes him down the road he ended up walking.

First, Bruce. His best friend. Twenty years. The man whose hand he held through everything. Not only stabbing him in the back - as if that’s not bad enough - but luring him out, bringing him to that exposed position in the first place. Yes, there’s Aiden’s own ego involved, but it’s Bruce who fed it and brought him to his resignation. And he only did it to take Aiden down.

Then Freya. Saying she disagrees with him about immigration. Isolating him. Then, meeting with Bruce. Alone. In private, at home, with drinks. Practically doing it behind Aiden’s back. If Bruce was the one who stabbed him in the back, Freya was the one who twisted the knife. Over and over and over again.

You see, it’s our darkest moments that set the tone of who we become. Betrayal and anger and pain and humiliation. 

3. Both Aiden and Freya have a part in it

That’s not to say that Aiden was innocent. Not in the slightest. He tried to use Freya. He hurt her - physically and emotionally. He tried to force her out of the way in any way he could (from getting her pregnant again to his final move on Bruce). He’s done an awful lot of wrong things. 

But so has she. Aiden acted on betrayal. But it didn’t have to come to that. She practically slapped him in the face in front of the entire country. And then she went on and hid her meetings with the man who betrayed him in the first place. When all she needed to do, from the very first moment, from the second she took the new job, was to talk to him. To actually sit down and talk.

And you know what? Under the circumstances, I understand Aiden’s actions (all except for the rape, that’s wrong in any context and case). You’d go to terrible lengths to hurt those who’ve hurt you. Especially if they’re people you’ve trusted, the people closest to you. I don’t necessarily agree with his actions - they could’ve avoided so much if they just talked instead of letting the situation escalate like that, and his fault as much as it’s hers - but I understand him. I understand where he’s coming from. I understand her fear, her desire to keep her family whole, but hiding away is never the answer. Particularly when you’re a public figure; there is no hiding away.

It just hurts to see them losing this beautiful solid relationship. Going from Aiden trying to stop her from coming to face the media with him after his resignation (”and risk taking you down with me?”) and Freya holding him later on that day, to those two people who just keep hurting each other and pushing each other away. It was so beautiful.

tags: have i got news for you

blog.title: Wasting my wibbly wobbly timey wimey!
blog.description: I love Doctor Who. So 98% of what I reblog is Doctor Who related. The other stuff I reblog is misc. non-fandom stuff. I ship TenRose a lot of you couldn't tell(and just the Doctor x Rose in general). So only follow me if you can tolerate most of my posts being TenRose related,
